Next, the fifth benefit of hearing the Dharma, which brings peace and happiness to all humans and gods, refers to what kind of Dharma?
Namely, it is said that the Dharma teaches all the methods of giving, and teaches all good dharmas.
Among all the revered ones, hearing the Dharma is the most supreme, able to cut off the root of all arrogance.
Namely, the Dharma teaches, able to tame arrogance.
The Dharma teaches, hears the Dharma, respects and values the Dharma, teaches the Dharma of faith, teaches the Dharma of upholding, and teaches the practitioner not to depart from the Dharma.
The buddhas and tathÄgatas take the Dharma as their teacher, let alone the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas.
Teaching the Dharma has ten merits, benefiting many.
What are the ten?

The time and place are complete, the distinctions are easy to understand, and it accords with the Dharma. It is not for the sake of profit, but to subdue the mind and speak the Dharma in accordance with it. It speaks of the rewards of giving, the many obstacles of the Dharma of birth and death, the decline of the heavens, and the existence of karmic fruits.
If the Dharma speaker has these ten qualities, it will enable the listeners to obtain much merit, benefit, and comfort, up to nirvana.
The listener and the Dharma speaker will each accomplish their wishes according to their aspirations.
Among all kinds of giving, the giving of Dharma is supreme, up to enabling all beings to attain the bliss of nirvana.
Furthermore, the merit of listening to the Dharma:
Accomplishing the profound mind, the faculty of faith is pure, and one-pointedly believes in the Three Jewels.
Going to the place of listening to the Dharma, in order to hear the true Dharma, with each step one takes, one gives rise to the merit of Brahma.
If a person makes offerings to a Dharma teacher who expounds the Dharma, one should know that this person is making offerings to the World-Honored One of the present age.

This person, in this way, according to the offerings made, will accomplish their wishes, and will attain supreme perfect enlightenment, because they are able to make offerings to the Dharma teacher who expounds the Dharma.
Why is this?
Because by hearing the Dharma, the mind is able to be tamed;
because it is tamed, one is able to cut off the ignorance and darkness of cyclic existence.
If one is apart from hearing the Dharma, there is not a single Dharma that is able to tame the mind.
As for hearing the expounding of the Dharma, there are four kinds of kindness that are extremely difficult to repay.
What are the four?
First, a mother;
second, a father;
third, a TathÄgata;
fourth, a Dharma teacher who expounds the Dharma.

If there are those who make offerings to these four kinds of people, they will attain immeasurable blessings, be praised by people in the present world, and in future lives will be able to attain enlightenment.
Why is this?
By the power of expounding the Dharma, the arrogant become subdued, the greedy come to believe in giving, the coarse become gentle, and the ignorant gain wisdom.
By the power of hearing the Dharma, those who are confused about cause and effect attain right faith.
By the power of hearing the Dharma, those with wrong views enter into right views.
By the power of hearing the Dharma, those who delight in killing, stealing, and sexual misconduct come to abandon them.
By the causes and conditions of expounding the Dharma and taming [beings], one will ultimately attain nirvÄá¹‡a.
For these causes and conditions, it is very difficult to repay the Dharma teacher who expounds the Dharma.
The kindness of parents is difficult to repay, because they give birth to the body, therefore the kindness of parents cannot be repaid.
If one can cause one's parents to abide in the Dharma, it is called repaying a little of their kindness.

The TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One, supreme in the three realms, liberator from birth and death, unsurpassed great teacher, this kindness is difficult to repay. There is only one Dharma that can repay the Buddha's kindness, namely, if one deeply understands and attains unshakable faith in the Buddha's teachings, this is called repaying kindness.
By making offerings in this way, one also benefits oneself.
At that time, the Bodhisattva Peacock King spoke a verse of the sutra, saying:
By the cause and condition of expounding the Dharma, one attains peaceful nirvana,
Able to sever all bonds, the great teacher of sentient beings.
By expounding the tranquil Dharma, one can sever the net of delusion,
Such a supreme guide is able to show the path to sentient beings.
If the Dharma enables sentient beings to transcend the ocean of existence,
This Dharma is most excellent, worldly dharmas cannot compare.
If a person is able to make offerings to these four kinds of fields of merit,
Such a person obtains good fruits, the guide teaches like this.
Having obtained all the faculties, and also being able to hear the Buddha's teachings,
If one practices non-dharma, regretting later is of no use.
Giving rise to attachment everywhere, always seeking sensual pleasures,
Always greedy for wife and children, not aware of death's arrival.
Moment by moment, there are many evils, disturbed by various faults,
With the mind binding sentient beings, leading them to the three evil paths.
This evil is difficult to subdue, always seeking opportunities for gods and humans,
This mind cannot be trusted, the great enemy of sentient beings.
Through hearing the good and seeing the good, cultivating immeasurable kinds,
Subduing the mind with the Dharma, like a horse obtaining a bridle.

benefiting the heavenly multitudes, expounding such Dharma and the path of karma, respecting and praising the Dharma teacher. The Bodhisattva Peacock King, by the power of his vows, was born in that heaven to benefit the gods.
When the heavenly multitudes had heard the Dharma, their minds became pure, and they all listened single-mindedly to what he said, saying:
What the Peacock King says is consistent and not inconsistent. It is consistent with what the Heavenly King of Tranquility in Tuá¹£ita Heaven says, without difference or distinction.

Contemplate this Dharma, which is good in the beginning, middle, and end, supremely pure, the foremost good Dharma, the foremost peace and security, benefiting and bringing peace and happiness to all heavenly and human beings, enabling them to attain tranquility.
At that time, the Peacock King, having heard what the Tuá¹£ita Heaven said, was delighted and his mind became pure. With a compassionate mind, he benefited all the heavenly multitudes up to nirvana.
Furthermore, it is said that the sixth profound and excellent Dharma door can lead to nirvana. Such a Dharma is the most peaceful and supreme, loved by the masses, namely the mind of compassion.

All people love it, causing people to give rise to faith, comforting sentient beings who are afraid of birth and death, causing those with uneasy minds to attain peace, and acting as a refuge for those without a savior.
If one has a compassionate mind, then one is not far from nirvana.
The compassionate mind is gentle, without deceit or roughness, and can eliminate the mind of anger, because the compassionate mind is moistening.
Moreover, the compassionate mind is called the great adornment.
If one gives rise to a compassionate mind towards sentient beings in the five realms, one can destroy anger and distress.
How does one give rise to a compassionate mind towards sentient beings in the hells?
How is it that these sentient beings are deceived by their own karma?
Due to the creation of the enemy of the mind, they attain various great sufferings that cannot be compared.

Iron hooks and iron pestles, molten copper blazing, evil insects devouring, the difficult-to-cross turbulent river drowning beings, vultures, crows, and magpies pecking at them, entering the forest of sword trees and the river of ashes to undergo various sufferings, indescribable.
Namely, the hells of living, black rope, gathering, wailing, great wailing, burning, and great burning, up to the AvÄ«ci Hell and its surrounding hells, a total of one hundred and thirty-six places.

Beings falling into them, shattered, split, cut, burned and cooked, deceived by their own minds, bound by the net of karma, burned by the fire of craving, without rescue or refuge, running around in the four directions, begging for mercy to save themselves and seek protection:
When will I be able to cross this great ocean of suffering?
Toward these beings, he gives rise to a compassionate mind.
If one plants such seeds of compassion, one will become a heavenly king or a wheel-turning sage king, loved and respected by all beings.
A compassionate person delights in wholesome actions.
This is called observing the sentient beings in hell suffering greatly and giving rise to compassion, thereby attaining immeasurable merit and blessings of the Brahma world.
Furthermore, if Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and other good people benefit sentient beings, they should observe hungry ghosts and give rise to compassion.
How do sentient beings fall into the realm of hungry ghosts?

Various kinds of hunger and thirst burn their bodies, like burning a forest. They run around in all directions, bumping into each other. Blazing flames burn them, their entire bodies are ablaze, they have no rescuers and no place to return to. They run everywhere in search of rescue, but there is no one who can save them.
When will these sentient beings be free from various kinds of suffering and distress?
When will they be able to end the suffering of hunger, thirst, and exhaustion?
This is called observing the suffering of hungry ghosts and giving rise to compassion.
Furthermore, if a Å›ramaá¹‡a, brÄhmaá¹‡a, or other good person contemplates the animals and gives rise to a mind of compassion,
within the realm of animals there are immeasurable sufferings, mutually killing each other.
Animals have three abodes: the sky, water, and land. The methods of death are immeasurable, mutually harming and devouring each other. When will these beings be liberated from this?
This is called contemplating the suffering of animals and giving rise to a mind of compassion.
If one is able to give rise to such thoughts, one will be reborn in the Brahma Heaven, because one contemplates sentient beings with a compassionate mind.

Contemplating sentient beings in the three evil destinies in places of great suffering and distress, in the place of the greatest evil karmic fruits, having given rise to a compassionate mind, one then gives rise to a compassionate mind for the gods in the six desire heavens.

In the six desire heavens, the heavenly pleasures are indescribable. In various valleys, mountain peaks, gardens, and forests, they experience happiness. In lotus groves and ponds, they play with heavenly maidens and experience hundreds of thousands of pleasures.
Having enjoyed pleasures, when their karma is exhausted, they fall back and are reborn in places of suffering, experiencing great suffering, falling into hell, hungry ghosts, or animals.
In this place of birth and death, beings are toyed with, bound by the chains of love, running around in all directions, confused and ignorant, experiencing great suffering.
This is called observing the suffering of the heavens and giving rise to a mind of compassion.

Furthermore, if a Å›ramaá¹‡a, brÄhmaá¹‡a, or other person observes among humans and gives rise to a mind of compassion, through various karmas they are born among humans, experiencing the fruits of suffering and happiness.

Beings of the upper, middle, and lower realms have various karmic activities, various mental natures, and various beliefs. Some are poor and rely on others, jealous and obstructive, afraid of being looked down upon by others, and pursue work to sustain themselves.
Contemplating the human world in this way, one gives rise to a compassionate mind. Such a compassionate mind is the foremost pure dharma that can attain nirvana.
' Contemplating the five kinds of suffering of the five realms in this way, one gives rise to a compassionate mind. Such a person attains supreme peace and security and then attains nirvana.'
At that time, the peacock king Bodhisattva spoke the verses of the TathÄgata Kakucchanda:
'If a person's mind is soft and compassionate, adorning himself,

If compassion is in the heart, this treasure is inexhaustible.

Hatred and distress cannot dwell in one's mind.
Having ascended the raft of compassion, with a mind of pity and valor,
One can cross the ocean of existence, with the great whirlpools of the three poisons.
The merit of this surpasses the construction of cities, and there is no adornment that surpasses this,
It is loved by the virtuous, and therefore it is called the mind of compassion.'

In this way, the Bodhisattva Peacock King spoke the Dharma for the devas, with good beginning, middle, and end, in accordance with tranquility and cessation. The entire assembly of devas enjoyed gathering to listen and receive it.
'Furthermore, that Buddha BhagavÄn spoke of the seventh Dharma, namely, what Dharma, in accordance with which, one attains liberation and cuts off negligence.
By what kind of karma?
Namely, a gentle mind, cutting off the fault of restlessness, and gathering all merits.
If there are people who can be gentle and sincere, free from all defilements, then nirvana and liberation will be as close as their hands.
A gentle person's mind is like white copper, practicing good deeds, trusted by many.
A coarse and harsh mind is like a diamond, always not forgetting the mind of enmity and resentment, behaving without self-control, disliked by many, unloved and untrusted;
If one gives rise to an evil mind and stubbornly refuses to let go, the mind will be uneasy, not enjoying meditation and recitation, not befriending good people, and not giving rise to good dharmas.

Like a saline field that does not produce seeds, or like sand that does not produce sesame oil, a coarse and harsh person is also like this, not giving rise to good dharmas, like milk from a cow's horns, like warmth in the moon, like a barren woman's child, like flowers in the sky.
Coarse and evil karma, deception and ignorance, deceiving oneself and others, sinking in the five destinies, befriending the unwholesome, abandoning the Three Jewels.

This blind man does not see the sun of the right Dharma's wisdom-illumination, and is very pitiable. He enters the great wilderness and experiences immeasurable suffering, far from the soft and sweet taste of the nectar.
Such an evil person sinks in the sea of suffering, far from nirvana.
Why is this?
Because he does not practice the causes and conditions of the path to nirvana.
For this reason, he never obtains happiness.

If a person can soften his mind, that person will definitely attain nirvana, just as the nature of hemp produces oil, the nature of the sun is light, the nature of moonlight is coolness, fire is hot, earth is solid, wind moves, and water is wet, with each of the four elements having its own nature without confusion.
A person with a soft mind tames his mind, has faith, diligence, and non-inverted views, and believes in cause and effect, then he is as if in the presence of nirvana.
'At that time, the peacock king Bodhisattva spoke a verse from the Buddha's scriptures, saying:
If a person's mind is pliant, like refined gold,
Such a person is good inside and out, and will quickly be freed from all suffering.
If a person's mental faculties are disciplined, and everything is pliant,
Such a person plants good seeds, like a fine rice field.
All sentient beings cannot exhaust this treasure,
It can destroy poverty and much deception.
Those with sharp faculties and tranquil minds, who always cultivate meditation,
Do not become attached to indulgent objects, and are forever free from all suffering and distress.'

When the Bodhisattva Peacock King had sung this verse, the assembly of YÄma Heaven and Tuá¹£ita Heaven, delighting in listening, were insatiable. Desiring to hear the Dharma again, they joined their palms in respect and said:
'Great Sage!
Please explain in detail the twenty-two dharmas for us.

At that time, the peacock king bodhisattva spoke to the heavenly beings about the twenty-two supreme Dharma doors. He has already spoken about seven dharmas, and now he will explain the eighth dharma in order.
'If there are Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and other good people who give rise to thoughts, what are the dharmas?
It is said that the dharma of self-restraint can serve as an adornment for all, and all self-restraint is in accord with the characteristics of vinaya.
If Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and other people, whether lay or ordained, old or young, are in accord with self-restraint, this adornment can make them upright.
If one is apart from self-restraint, it is like a jackal, crow, owl, or vulture.
How should one who has left the household life practice self-restraint?
One who has left the household life should first practice self-restraint with the kÄá¹£Äya robe and perform seven practices.
What are the seven?
First, according to the country's laws, accept discarded robes, the clothes abandoned by laypeople in the country where one resides.
If in a charnel ground there are clothes of the dead, those pressed down by corpses, then one should not take them;
if in a charnel ground one obtains damaged clothes, then one should accept and use them.
This is called the method of taming with the kasaya robe.
Next, the second taming.

If entering a village, observe the ground while walking, look ahead one fathom, contemplate the Buddha's image, single-mindedly recollect, the faculties undisturbed, count the in-and-out breaths, and focus the mind on the body.

Entering a village, do not look at all the necessary items, do not look at various utensils, also do not look at others' adornments and canopies, do not speak with women, do not hold small children, do not move the feet frequently, also do not move the arms and bed, do not rub the head with the hand, do not adjust the robes frequently, do not shake the kasaya robe, do not massage the hands or snap the fingers.
This is called the second method of taming.
Next, the third taming.
Entering the patron's house, when eating, wash the hands up to the wrist.
When receiving food, do not extend the hands too much, about one cubit in front, do not eat too much or too little.
When eating, do not play or joke, thinking one is not content, losing others' pure faith, causing others to despise, observe others' minds.
If the food is neither too large nor too small, do not open the mouth too wide, do not make sounds, and do not breathe heavily.
With regard to the appropriate food, only eat two-thirds, be content with the food, do not look at others' bowls and give rise to greedy thoughts.
When receiving food and drink, do not disturb others' minds, look at one's own bowl, and do not look around to the left and right.

After eating, put down the bowl, wash and rinse, guard the sense faculties, and expound the Dharma with a right mind. Think carefully, neither too slowly nor too quickly, neither crooked nor straight, do not speak at the wrong time, neither too much nor too little, protect the donor's mind, and do not destroy their faith.
This is called the third method of taming.
Next, the fourth taming.

If at mealtime, whether in a village or city, do not think of the food seen before, do not speak frequently, and do not hope for the bedding received. Accept and keep it according to the Dharma, do not seek the best.
This is called the fourth method of self-discipline.
Next, the fifth self-discipline.

Not relying on or attached to anything one does, not sparing one's body or life, not accumulating too many requisites, not going to dangerous border regions, not wearing unusual clothing, not enjoying invitations, not favoring one household over another.
This is called the fifth method of self-discipline.
Next, the sixth self-discipline.
Not cutting grass or digging the earth, not wearing multicolored leather shoes or multicolored clothing.
If others break the precepts, not slandering or speaking of them.
Not hoping for the king's food, not befriending quarrelsome monks.
This is called the sixth method of self-discipline.
Next, the seventh self-discipline.

If there are bhiká¹£us who have the same understanding and practice the same Dharma, they should be closely associated with and benefited, causing them to always cross over. If they wish to abandon the realm of MÄra, be tranquil and subdued, and guard the sense faculties, such bhiká¹£us should be closely associated with.
If in a mountain cave, a mountain stream, under a tree, or in the open, always practice emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness.
This is called the seventh method of subduing.
If there are bhiká¹£us who are able to practice in this way, they will be able to abandon all bonds and attain liberation.'
At that time, the Bodhisattva Peacock King, for the sake of the heavenly multitudes, spoke in verse, saying:
The characteristics of the method of subduing are in accord with the realm of wisdom and practice,
Fearing the faults of birth and death, then leaving the home life is not in vain.
The precepts are not violated, not thinking of former pleasures,
Always contemplating the aggregates, one should dwell in a quiet forest.
Soft words and the person of tranquility, manifesting the path to nirvana,
Upholding the precepts and adorning the body, in accord with the appearance of leaving the household life.
If one is able to not be confused within one's own and others' dharmas,
The retribution of karma and the non-retribution of karma, the path and the non-path are also like this.
Departing from evil karmic actions, not fearing suffering and joy,
Liberated from the household, bound by various sufferings.

' Thus the Peacock King spoke of the immeasurable merits of self-discipline, causing the heavenly multitudes to all attain faith and understanding. The entire assembly of gods listened single-mindedly and attentively.

' What is called the pure Dharma of impurity?
If Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and others in the world have faith in the retribution of karma, because they have faith in the retribution of karma, they will attain the great Dharma.

If Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and others in the world have faith in the fruits of karma, such a person will be able to know the evil karma of the body, and will not cultivate and increase the evil karma of the body, will not love or enjoy it, because the fruits it brings will be in the evil realms of hell, hungry ghosts, and animals.
In this way, he will not cultivate and increase the evil karma of speech, will not love or enjoy it, because he will experience the evil fruits of hell, hungry ghosts, and animals.
In this way, he will not cultivate and increase the evil karma of the mind, will not love or enjoy it, because he will experience the suffering of hell, hungry ghosts, and animals.

If a Å›ramaá¹‡a or brÄhmaá¹‡a has previously committed evil karma, and after thinking about it, regrets it, stops, and does not do it again, and gets close to teachers and listens to the Dharma from them, how can he escape the fruits of evil karma?

In this way, the teacher or elder who has wisdom and self-control will explain the causes and conditions, speak skillfully, and cause them to repent of their past evil karma, which will then be completely extinguished.
Because of this kind of thought of wholesome karma, they will not create evil karma.

Contemplating the causes and conditions of karma, from where do they arise? Contemplating in this way, they will not create evil karma, and will be able to gradually eliminate all unwholesome karma, or make it lighter. The unwholesome karma of body, speech, and mind that is created in the present will, because of the lightness of the mind, be quickly regretted after it is done, and will not be done again. If the mind of repentance is like this, then even if the karma is accomplished, all evil karma will be completely extinguished.
If Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and others in the world understand karma in this way, they will think like this:
I have cultivated evil and will create evil karma with my body, speech, and mind. When the retribution ripens, I will fall into hell, the realm of hungry ghosts, or the animal realm.
They use right means to prevent unwholesome actions that have not yet arisen from arising.

If Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as can have such faith in the results of karma, even if they have created evil karma that should lead to hell, they should experience great suffering in hell for a long time, but they may experience a small amount or it may all be eliminated.

Furthermore, because of diligent effort, if there is evil karma that should lead to rebirth as a hungry ghost, they will be a hungry ghost for a long time, experiencing the great suffering of hunger and thirst, but they may experience it for a short time or it may all be eliminated.

In this way, if Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and other beings have evil karma that should lead to rebirth as an animal, they will be an animal for a long time, devouring each other, but they may experience it for a short time or it may all be eliminated.

Except for those who have created and practiced with determination and will definitely experience the results in whatever realm - if in the realms of hell, hungry ghosts, or animals, they will definitely experience the results.
Furthermore, having faith in the results of karma, contemplate the subtle results of karma that are difficult to understand.
Having repented of the three kinds of evil deeds, one does not commit them again.
Due to indeterminate karma, one is born in the animal realm.
Thinking like this:
If the karma for hell or the karma for hungry ghosts results in a birth as an animal, a repentant mind can purify and destroy heavy karma.
Due to the power of the mind, either all [karma] is extinguished or a small part is severed.

If one should experience the evil karma of the animal realm, a repentant mind can destroy it. One's own karma can destroy it, and one does not receive a long-lived animal body, nor does one experience great suffering. Or, with a superior mind, one can sever evil karma.
For this reason, one should believe in the fruits of karma.
If Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and others believe in the fruits of karma, they will be able to reach the other shore of birth and death.
Why is this?
In all the five destinies of birth and death, there is existence due to the fruits of good and evil karma. Therefore, one should believe in the true fruits of karma.
All sentient beings are given [this] due to the causes and conditions of all karmic fruits.
Therefore, whether male or female, one should diligently cultivate, contemplating day and night that the fruits of karma are the most enduring in the cycle of birth and death.
Next, the tenth.
If Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and other people should contemplate, what kind of dharmas should they contemplate?

If Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and other people with little wisdom are harmed by dwelling, their minds delight in attachment and are reluctant to let go, whether in a monastery, a place where monks dwell, a village, a country, a city, or other places, they always delight in laziness, delight in improper places, do not go to the peaceful and secluded places, do not go to other places, are not called householders, are not called renunciants, and until the end of their lives, they are in improper places.
For what reasons do such people go forth?
They do not go to the appropriate mountains, forests, or solitary places, but rather exhaust their lives in inappropriate places.

If Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as dwell in inappropriate places, they will be despised by benefactors, and will not be happy to associate with them, make offerings to them, or see them.

Such and such a Å›ramaá¹‡a, such and such a brÄhmaá¹‡a, and other people, enjoy dwelling in inappropriate places.

They are neither called householders nor renunciants. They do not enjoy the mountains, forests, or solitary places. They hoard wealth, enjoy seeing worldly people, associate with householders like servants, and are despised by the laity.
Therefore, this person is neither called a layperson nor a renunciant, because they abide in an improper place.
Even if they are without faults, they may be slandered by others.
There is not a single person who abides in an improper place and is not despised by their benefactors.
They are often seen associating with laypeople or being close to householders. Although they may not be despised, they may give rise to other faults.
If Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as abide in improper places, because they abide in improper places, they will not attain benefit.

Therefore, Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as should not abide in ruined places. They should always enjoy abiding in places, always enjoy solitary places, enjoy staying under trees, enjoy staying in charnel grounds, enjoy staying in quiet places, cultivating meditation in silence, or going alone in the mountains and valleys until the end of their lives.
They should avoid improper places, abandon all improper places, and be able to attain liberation;
those who abide in improper places cannot attain liberation.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
